The pre-activation of Cu-based catalysts is an important step to fully develop their catalytic potential. The production of active species (Cu+ and Cu0) which play the active site role generally occurs in the activation stage by reducing from Cu2+. Herein, the Cu+/Cu0 ratio of CuZnOAl2O3 (CZA) catalysts was adjusted using different activation atmospheres and the relationship between Cu+/Cu0 ratio of the catalyst and methanol selectivity from CO2 hydrogenation was investigated in detail. Combined with X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation spectroscopy (DRIFTS) characterization, etc. and experimental results, it was observed that the selectivity of methanol was obviously relied on the Cu+/Cu0 ratio of CZA catalyst. This work provides theoretical guidance and feasible scheme to rationally design and optimize the required catalysts. Graphical abstract The Cu+/Cu0 ratio of the Cu-based catalyst was adjusted by activation of different atmospheres to improve the selectivity for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Cu-based catalyst Activation Cu+/Cu0 Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol is one of research object of attention due to a series of chain reactions caused by carbon emission [1-6]. Cu-based catalyst plays an important role in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol due to its advantages of low cost and high activity, which can accelerate the reaction rate and has a good catalytic effect at low temperature [6-8]. Although Cu-based catalysts have high activity, this comes from a favorable activation process. The activation of Cu-based catalysts is a critical step and sensitive process that allows them to completely present their catalytic potential [8]. In general, the activation process is equivalent to the reduction of CuO to Cu+ or Cu0 by reducing gases such as H2 at high temperature [8,9]. The control of activation condition is a very important factor, including the heating rate, the appropriate activation temperature, activation time in the activation process of the catalyst [9]. Meanwhile, different atmospheres may result in various changes to the surface and internal structure of Cu species. Huang et al. obtained different morphologies of Cu nanoparticles after reduction in different atmospheres, and explored the influence of the morphology of Cu nanoparticles on the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol [10]. In our previous work, the physicochemical properties of the Cu-based catalyst were reconstructed through reasonable regulation of the activation process, which significantly improved the catalyst stability [11]. However, there is no consensus on the exact role of Cu as the active substance itself in the hydrogenation reaction. In particular, the suitable surface distribution of Cu0 and Cu+ sites, which are most conducive to catalytic performance, has been the focus. It is generally believed that Cu0 is the main active phase, which generates the active site by adsorption of CO2 and H2, and further catalyzes CO2 and H2 to produce methanol, meanwhile Cu+ has high activity and selectivity for CO2 adsorption and reduction [12]. Previous studies mainly focused on adjusting and exploring the surface chemistry of Cu by adding additives or changing the preparation method [13,14]. Likozar et al. prepared a series of CuZnOAl2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol by different methods and discovered the trend of CH3OH productivity rate was consistent with the Cu0/Cu+ ratio [15]. Ma et al. compared a series of highly comparable Cu/SiO2 catalysts and demonstrated that, when the accessible metallic Cu surface area was below a certain value, the catalytic activity of hydrogenation linearly increased with increasing Cu surface area, whereas it was primarily affected by the Cu+ surface area [12]. Our previous work depicted that doped cerium additives in Cu/ZnO catalysts retained the Cu0/Cu+ ratio on the catalyst surface, and delayed the oxidation of Cu+ and particle growth due to the electronic interaction between Cu/Cu2O/CuO and Ce3+/Ce4+ [16]. In view of this, we used oxidation-reducing atmospheres for activation pretreatment of Cu-based catalyst, and by regulating the properties of active Cu species (Cu+/Cu0), the effect of atmospheric activation on physicochemical properties of Cu-based catalyst and the relationship between catalyst properties and active components were investigated. On the other hand, a series of characterization methods such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), temperature programmed desorption (TPD), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation spectroscopy (DRIFTS) were used. The results showed that the activation of different atmospheres had a great influence on the Cu species of the catalyst, and the appropriate activation process could help to improve the distribution of Cu+/Cu0 and thus improve the methanol selectivity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The classical CuZnOAl2O3 (6:3:1) catalyst was adopted in this work and was prepared by conventional co-precipitation method. A mixture containing 14.979 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 9.226 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 1.942 g Al(NO3)3·9H2O was prepared into 1 mol/L salt solution. 12.074 g Na2CO3 was dissolved in deionized water to form a 1 mol/L alkali solution. After the water bath was heated to 70 °C, the two solutions were rapidly added together through the peristaltic pump to form a suspension and the magnetic stirrer was continuously stirred so that the pH was maintained at 7 ± 0.2. After aging at 70 °C for 1 h, the suspension was filtered and washed with deionized water for 3 times. The filter cake was placed in the oven at 60 °C overnight and dried for 12 h. Finally, the precursor was roasted at 350 °C for 4 h to obtain the sample, which was recorded as CZA. 2.2 Catalysts activation The CZA catalysts were activated in different atmospheres, as shown in Scheme 1 . Firstly, the CZA catalysts were pre-reduced by 10 % H2/N2 and 10 % CO/N2 for 1 h marked as CZA-H2 and CZA-CO, respectively. After that, 10 % CO2/N2 was continued to be injected for oxidation treatment for 1 h marked as CZA-H2-CO2 and CZA-CO-CO2, respectively. The above activation was carried out at 300 °C and the activated catalysts were stored by vacuuming. 2.3 Catalysts characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was conducted using a TD-M001 diffractometer equipped with graphite-filtered Cu Kα radiation at room temperature. XRD patterns were obtained through step scanning at a rate of 8°/min, covering a 2θ range of 10° to 80°. The diffractometer was operated at an voltage of 40 kV and a current of 30 mA. To prevent the oxidation of the catalyst surface, it was necessary to store the catalyst in a vacuum dryer to ensure the accuracy of the obtained results. The mean crystallite size of Cu nanoparticles was determined using the Scherrer equation as following [17]. d C u = k λ β c o s θ which incorporated parameters such as the Sherrer constant (k = 0.89), the X-ray wavelength (λ = 0.154056 nm), the full width at half maximum of the diffraction peak (β), and the diffraction angle (θ). This equation allowed us to estimate the average size of the Cu nanoparticles based on the broadening of the diffraction peak. The dispersity of Cu species was determined using N2O chemisorption on the Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 system. A 40 mg sample was heated from 50 °C to 500 °C (10 °C/min) in a flow of 10 % H2/Ar fluid (30 mL/min), and recorded the H2 consumption as X. After reduction, the sample was cooled down to 50 °C and re-oxidized at 50 °C with N2O (30 mL/min) for 30 min. Subsequntly, the sample was flushed with a pure Ar fluid for 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed N2O. The catalyst was then reduced again according to the above procedure and the H2 consumption was recorded as Y. The dispersion of Cu species and the size of exposed Cu particles were calculated by the following formulas. Reduction of all Cu atoms: (1) CuO + H2 → Cu + H2O; H2 consumption = X Reduction of surface Cu atoms only: (2) Cu2O + H2 → 2Cu + H2O; H2 consumption = Y D Cu ( % ) = 2 Y X × 100 % S Cu = 2 × Y × N A X × M Cu × 1.4 × 10 19 = 1353 × Y X ( m 2 / g ) d Cu = 104.25 D Cu ( nm ) Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed with JEOL JEM-2100. A specified quantity of catalyst powder was dispersed into an ethanol solution. After the ultrasonic treatment for 40 min, the as-obtained suspension was dropped cast onto carbon-coated Cu grid and dried naturally. The prepared samples were photographed and characterized under the conditions of an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO temperature-programmed reduction (CO-TPR) were performed on the FINESORB-3010 equipment. Initially, 0.03 g of catalyst was loaded into a U-shaped quartz tube. The tube was then purged with Ar gas at 300 °C for 1 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the gas flow was switched to a mixture of 10 vol% H2/Ar or 10 vol% CO/He with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The temperature was subsequently increased to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray excitation Auger spectroscopy (XAES) analysis were carried out on ESCALab 220i-XL VG instrument. The energy spectrum was excited by Al Kα rays at a wavelength of 1486.6 eV. To ensure accurate measurements, the binding energy (BE) values were corrected using the C1s peak at 284.6 eV as a reference, with an uncertainty of ±0.1 eV. Photoelectron peak positions were reported using the binding energy (BE) and Auger peaks using the kinetic energy (KE). CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) analysis was conducted using the Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 equipment. In this process, 0.06 g of catalyst was placed into a U-shaped quartz tube. Initially, the sample was pretreated at 50 °C under an Ar flow. Subsequently, the gas was switched to pure CO2 for 1 h. Afterward, the system was purged with Ar for 0.5 h before heating the catalyst from 50 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min for desorption. The H2-TPD program followed the same procedure as the CO2-TPD analysis but 10 vol% H2/Ar was used. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was recorded using a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. The reduced catalysts were placed in a sample tray. Prior to in situ IR tests, all catalysts were pretreated under an Ar flow for 20 min at 250 °C. After pretreatment, the catalysts were exposed to 10 % CO2/Ar at 300 °C for 30 min and then switched 10 % CO2/Ar to H2/CO2=3:1 for another 30 min to record the evolution of surface species with reaction time. After the test background is collected, the gas is exchanged for several cycle tests. Deconvolution of the final spectra allowed us to qualitatively estimate the amount of certain species by integration of the areas under corresponding IR peaks. 2.4 Catalytic testing The catalytic performance was assessed in a continuous fixed reaction bed setup. Initially, 0.5 g of catalyst with a mesh size of 20–40 was loaded into a stainless steel reaction tube (Φ 9 mm × 1450 mm). The tube was then filled with quartz sand of the same size, both above and below the catalyst bed. After that, a mixture of H2: CO2: Ar = 72 vol%: 24 vol%: 4 vol% was passed into the reaction tube. Later, the reaction pressure was quickly elevated to 3 MPa. Then the reaction unit was heated to a range of 190–290 °C to investigate the influence of temperature. All the products from the reactor were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC). CO and CO2 were analyzed by a GC equipped with the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and two columns of 5A molecular sieve column (4 mm × 200 mm) and the GDX-104 packed column. Methanol was analyzed by another GC equipped with the flame ionization detector (FID) and a column of Porapak-Q (27.5 mm × 0.32 mm × 10 µm). Argon was added in the reaction feed as an internal standard for analysis. The CO2 conversion and products’ selectivity for all catalysts were adopted. The calculation equations are as followed [18]: X C O 2 ( % ) = ( 1 − A o u t ( C O 2 ) / A o u t ( A r ) A i n ( C O 2 ) / A i n ( A r ) ) × 100 % Where A i n ( C O 2 ) and A i n ( A r ) are the TCD peak areas of CO2 and Ar before reaction and A o u t ( C O 2 ) and A o u t ( A r ) are the TCD peak areas of CO2 and Ar after reaction. S ( C O ) ( % ) = A o u t ( C O ) / A o u t ( A r ) × f C O / A r ( A i n ( C O 2 ) / A i n ( A r ) − A o u t ( C O 2 ) / A o u t ( A r ) ) × f C O 2 / A r × 100 % S ( C H 3 O H ) ( % ) = ( A C H 3 O H × f C H 3 O H ( A i n ( C O 2 ) / A i n ( A r ) − A o u t ( C O 2 ) / A o u t ( A r ) ) × f C O 2 / A r ) × 100 % Where A o u t ( C O ) and A C H 3 O H are the peak areas of CO and CH3OH, respectively. f C O / A r , f C O 2 / A r , and f C H 3 O H are the calibration factors of CO, CO2, and CH3OH. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activation result According to Scheme 1 above, the activated catalysts of CZA-H2, CZA-CO, CZA-H2-CO2 and CZA-CO-CO2 with different Cu+/Cu0 ratios were prepared by altering activation atmospheres. It was reported that the morphology and chemical states of Cu nanoparticles is sensitive to the reaction environments [19]. For instance, more CO exposure could decrease the free Cu surface area, while the H2 reduction led to fully reduced and adsorbate-free Cu surfaces [20]. Thus, H2 and CO were selected as reducing gases considering their different reducing effect on CuO under certain conditions. H2-TPR and CO-TPR were used to examine the reduction behavior of the calcined CZA catalyst, as shown in Fig. 1 . The primary reduction of CZA catalyst in H2-Ar flow occurred at 183 °C with a broad reduction peak at lower temperature. The side peak at 165 °C might be contributed to the reduction of CuO to Cu2O [21]. In contrast, there was a dominant reduction peak in CO-He at 201 °C with the presence of a side peak at 183 °C, which is more pronounced than H2-Ar. This indicated that, compared with H2 reduction, the reduction of CO is more likely to be carried out in stages, with Cu2+ being reduced to Cu+ and then to Cu0 resulting in the formation of more Cu+. Table S1 shows the amounts of H2 and CO required for the reduction of Cu species and corresponding temperature ranges. In order to further regulate the valence state of Cu, CO2 was selected as soft oxidizing gas, which could result in weak oxidation of metallic Cu at high temperature [22]. This statement is further verified by the following characterization results. 3.2 Structural and morphology of the catalyst In order to study the effect of activation condition on the catalyst structure and crystal size, the XRD patterns of CZA catalyst at different stages are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that the peaks of Cu species are dominant and the weak peaks of ZnO are also detected. There is no Al2O3 diffraction peak appeared to indicate that a small amount of Al2O3 is evenly dispersed in the catalyst [23]. The CZA catalyst after calcination mainly exists in the form of CuO (JCPDS 05–0661), and the peak positions are at 2θ angles of 35.5° and 38.6°. On the other hand, the peaks of Cu2O (JCPDS 65–3288) and Cu (JCPDS 04–0836) located at 36.3° and 43.3°, respectively, appeared in all the CZA catalysts activated by different atmospheres. Particularly, the Cu peak of CZA-H2 is sharper than the value of CZA-CO, indicating that the crystallinity of Cu is higher [24]. However, both the large peak of Cu2O and small peak of Cu were detected in the CZA-H2-CO2 catalyst, while the peak of CuO was mainly detected in the CZA-CO-CO2 catalyst. Both of them showed diffraction peaks mainly in the oxidized state of Cu. Therefore, CO2 can reduce the reduction degree of CZA catalyst, which Cu+ and Cu0 species could be partially converted to higher valence state. The results showed that the main active phase Cu of CZA catalyst changed greatly after activation in different atmospheres, and existed in the form of Cu0, Cu+ and Cu2+. It can preliminarily infer the formation of four catalysts with different Cu+/Cu0 ratios by the XRD results. Meanwhile, the grain size of Cu calculated by Scherrer's method was between 8 and 13 nm. The morphology and particle size of the catalysts at different stages were studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 3 , all the activated catalysts have similar morphology and good dispersion of Cu. The particle size of Cu species in CZA-H2 catalyst (8.83 nm) is slightly lower than CZA-CO catalyst (9.46 nm). This is related to the reducing ability of H2, which can more thoroughly reduce the Cu in the bulk phase [25,26]. After being treated with CO2, the particle size of Cu species slightly increased. CZA-H2-CO2 catalyst (11.21 nm) and CZA-CO-CO2 catalyst (12.42 nm) underwent some degree of oxidation under the action of CO2, and the formed oxides leaded to an increase in particle size [27]. This indicated that the average particle size of the catalyst was changed by different atmosphere activation, as manifested in the state change of the active Cu species. To study the contribution of Cu species to the reaction, other factors (such as the size and dispersion of metal particles) should first be excluded. The particle size and dispersion of active Cu obtained from the chemisorption results of N2O are shown in Table 1 . Indeed, the Cu dispersion of catalysts activated is decrease with lower degree of reduction. Meanwhile, the surface area of Cu in activated CZA catalysts are about 60∼80 m2·g−1 that the small difference in the specific surface area of Cu is only caused by the reduction and oxidation of Cu species. The surface area difference of less than 16 m2·g−1 ensures the consistency of the total active Cu amount. The mean particle size was estimated based on the chemisorption data of N2O and the calculated results are similar to the previous XRD and TEM results. However, there is no structure-activity relationship between catalyst performance and particle size change. It follows that the particle size of Cu species is not the key factor affecting the initial activity of the catalyst. 3.3 Chemical states and distribution of surface species In order to observe the effect of activation on Cu valence state more directly. The chemical state and composition of Cu on the surface of CZA catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 4 (a) and (b) show the Cu 2p spectra of the activated CZA catalysts. The activated CZA catalyst exhibited two binding energy peaks at 932.0 eV and 952.0 eV, belonging to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively [28,29]. However, strong satellite Cu2+ peaks near 940∼945 eV and 962.0 eV appeared in the Cu 2p spectra of the oxidized CZA-CO-CO2 catalyst that further indicated the oxidation of Cu+ and Cu0 as shown in Fig. 4(b). To further determine the content of Cu+ and Cu0 species, the peak fitting of Cu LMM XAES spectra was carried out, as shown in Fig. 4(c) and (d). There are overlapping peaks at 916.6 eV and 918.5 eV that can be used to distinguish Cu+ and Cu0 species in the spectrum. It can be seen that the intermediate valence of Cu had greatly changed, as well as the sharp change of the ratio of Cu+/Cu0 with the different activation atmosphere. The Cu+/Cu0 ratio of CZA-H2 catalyst was lower than that of CZA-CO catalyst, implying the generation of more Cu0 species. This was consistent with TPR results that H2 and CO exhibited different reduction effects on Cu species. The CZA catalysts after CO2 oxidation also formed more Cu+ as shown in Fig. 4(d). The contents and proportions of Cu+ and Cu0 in each stage of CZA catalyst are shown in Table 2 . It is obvious that Cu+/Cu0 of the activated CZA catalysts are different and increase with decrease of the degree of reduction, the order is CZA-H2 (1.43) < CZA-CO (2.24) < CZA-H2-CO2 (4.24) < CZA-CO-CO2 (8.35). The results of XPS characterization well confirm the idea that the Cu+/Cu0 ratio was regulated by different atmospheres in this work, and were consistent with other characterization results above. According to previous reports, the electronic state of Cu at metal/support interfaces would significantly affect the binding strength of intermediates. In view of Cu may be affected by the electronic action of Zn from the metal supported interaction [30,31]. However, it can be seen from the Zn 2p and Zn LMM spectra that the electron valence states of Zn had not been significantly shifted, as shown in Fig. S2. Therefore, it is proved that the electron of Cu is only related to its own valence change. 3.4 The adsorption properties of catalysts In order to study the real surface properties and adsorption properties of the activated catalyst, the CO2 and H2 desorption profiles of the CZA catalysts after activation in different atmospheres are shown in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 5(a), all the samples showed two main peak patterns, corresponding to a weak desorption peak near 110 °C and a strong desorption peak near 370 °C, respectively [32,33]. The peak area of the sample was variable, indicating the activated CZA catalysts have different strength of CO2 adsorption. Previous studies had shown that the increased selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was related to the interaction of CO2 on the catalyst surface [34,35]. Considering that the actual reaction temperature is between 190 and 290 °C, the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is mainly affected by the second high temperature CO2 resolution peak [36]. The peak at low temperature is attributed to the surface Brønsted base i.e. surface -OH group, while the peak at high temperature is due to metal oxygen pairs [37]. The CO2 adsorption is widely considered to significantly affect the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, especially the strong basic adsorption [38,39]. Therefore, we discussed CO2 adsorption species only at higher temperature in detail and calculate the number of different CO2 desorption species, as shown in Table S2. According to the deconvolution results of CO2-TPD, the CO2 desorption peaks of the catalysts activated with different atmospheres have some differences in the strong basic adsorption sites. Although there is no obvious difference in the analytical quantity of weak basic adsorption site, the analytical of strong basic adsorption site decrease in the order of CZA-H2-CO2 > CZA-CO > CZA-H2 > CZA-CO-CO2. The higher the peak intensity, the stronger the CO2 adsorption and activation ability. The main reason for the difference is the change of CO2 adsorption capacity caused by the various Cu+/Cu0. When the Cu+/Cu0 is in a certain range, it is conducive to CO2 adsorption. This can be interpreted as the partial adsorption of CO2 depends on the Cu+ or Cu° formed on the catalyst surface or even the synergistic effect of both [40]. H2 as another of the reactants, there are also two main desorption peaks in Fig. 5(b) belonging to α peak near 130 °C and β peak near 400 °C. There is no significant change in the adsorption capacity of activated catalyst for H2. Therefore, the adsorption of H2 was not affected by the change of Cu valence state. 3.5 Effect of Cu+/Cu0 on reaction intermediates In situ DRIFT adsorption of feedstock gas was used to detect. surface reaction intermediates on each catalyst to verify the important role of Cu+/Cu0 ratio in CO2 hydrogenation. Prior to this, the activated catalyst was first exposed to CO2 atmosphere for 30 min, and its adsorption of CO2 was observed, as shown in Fig. S3. It is obvious that CZA catalyst with different Cu+/Cu0 ratio has different adsorption strength for CO2, and the results are consistent with CO2-TPD. Fig. 6 shows the DRIFT spectra of the activated catalysts exposed to CO2 and H2 atmosphere for 30 min at a reaction temperature of 250 °C, which over the range 1000 to 3100 cm−1 to reveal the behavior of intermediates adsorption. It has been demonstrated that the IR bands at 2820 and 2952 cm−1 are attributable to the asymmetric and symmetric C-H stretching vibrations of H3CO*, respectively [41,42]. The peak at 2886 cm−1 can be attributed to the C-H stretching vibration of the adsorbed H3CO* species on the Cu species. The strong adsorption modes at 1540 cm−1 and 1387 cm−1 arise from the asymmetric νas(O-C-O) and νs(O-C-O) stretching modes, respectively. These may come from adsorbed carbonate (CO3*) or formate (HCOO*) intermediates, but it has been confirmed that formate (HCOO*) act as methanol formation intermediate on Cu-based catalysts [43]. Fig. 6(c) shows the adsorption mode at 1081 cm−1 is ascribed to the ν(C-O) mode in accumulating methoxy or adsorbed H2CO*, which have been also confirmed as an intermediate on Cu-based catalyst, and its hydrogenation reaction is also considered to be a rate-determining step in methanol synthesis [44,45]. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the peak of methoxy is absent and the peaks of formate are visible. It is obvious that the adsorption strength of the four catalysts for the intermediates is CZA-H2-CO2 > CZA-CO > CZA-H2 > CZA-CO-CO2. In particular, there are strong HCOO* and CH3O* groups and weak H2CO* vibration peaks on CZA-H2-CO2 and CZA-CO catalysts. The results showed that the activation of catalyst in different atmospheres affected the formation and adsorption of methanol intermediates by tuning Cu+/Cu0 ratio of CAZ catalyst. As the Cu+/Cu0 ratio of activated CZA catalyst increasing, the adsorption of CO2 is more intense, and formates and methoxyl are more easily formed and adsorbed. However, when the ratio is too high, it is not conducive to the formation and adsorption of methanol intermediates. 3.6 Catalyst performance The performance evaluation of the catalysts with different Cu+/Cu0 ratio after activation in different atmosphere are shown in Fig. 7 (a). CH3OH and CO are mainly the carbon containing products under the reaction conditions. The CO2 conversion of activated CZA catalysts are higher than 5 % under reaction conditions, which ensure the detection accuracy of catalytic performance. Although CO2 conversion increases with increasing temperature, it does not seem to be significantly affected by different Cu+/Cu0 ratios. Especially at 250 °C, the CO2 conversion of all catalysts are about 20 %. On the contrary, CH3OH selectivity of CZA catalysts decreased with the increase of temperature and there is a great difference between these catalysts for CH3OH selectivity that decreased in the order of CZA-H2-CO2 > CZA-CO > CZA-H2 > CZA-CO-CO2 under the same conditions. It can be seen that the CH3OH selectivity of CZA-H2, CZA-CO, CZA-H2-CO2, CZA-CO-CO2 catalysts with different Cu+/Cu0 ratios at 230 °C are 56 %, 60 %, 67 % and 39 %, respectively. Moreover, after further CO2 oxidation, the CH3OH selectivity of CZA-H2-CO2 catalyst and CZA-CO-CO2 catalyst show the opposite change. The methanol selectivity of the catalyst was relatively high when Cu+/Cu0 was relatively moderate, indicating that Cu+/Cu0 play an important role in the catalytic process, which is conducive to the formation of methanol. However, it is interesting to find that the CZA-CO-CO2 catalyst with a higher Cu+/Cu0 ratio shows the lowest methanol selectivity. According to above characterization analysis, H2 is more reductive than CO under certain conditions that resulting in a higher degree of CuO reduction. In addition, CO2 can oxidize Cu species under certain conditions. These activation processes have the most pronounced effect on the change in the valence state of Cu within the CZA catalysts. Thus, modulating the valence state of Cu, particularly in the form of a certain ratio of Cu+/Cu0, represents an effective approach to enhance the performance of the CZA catalyst. With the increase of Cu+/Cu0 ratio, the performance of CZA catalysts also gradually improve, but it decrease when reaching a certain proportion. The relationship between CH3OH selectivity and Cu+/Cu0 ratio in this work is shown in Fig. 7(b). Under the given reaction conditions, as the Cu+/Cu0 ratio increases, the selectivity of methanol initially rises and then declines, exhibiting a characteristic volcanic trend. When Cu+/Cu0 ratio is 4.24, CH3OH selectivity reaches the maximum under reaction conditions. It should be pointed out that the catalytic performance of the CZA-H2 -CO2 catalyst prepared by us for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is better than that benchmark of the reported Cu-based catalysts, as shown in the Table 3 . This indicates the importance of using different activation means to replace traditional H2 reduction to regulate Cu+/Cu0. When the reduction degree of catalyst is moderate, the balance between Cu+ and Cu° can be maintained, both Cu+ and Cu0 active sites play an indispensable role in the hydrogenation process. The proper Cu+/Cu0 ratio helps the formation and adsorption of methanol intermediates which is conducive to improve methanol selectivity from CO2 hydrogenation. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a method of controlling the change in Cu species of CZA catalyst has been proposed by adjusting the activation atmosphere. By manipulating the composition of the reduction or oxidation atmosphere, it was easily to obtain the CZA catalysts with different Cu+/Cu0 ratios. Among them, the CZA-H2-CO2 (Cu+/Cu0 = 4.24) catalyst exhibited a moderately reduced state, which had strong CO2 adsorption capacity for improving methanol selectivity (81.9 %), followed by the CZA-CO (Cu+/Cu0 = 2.24) catalyst (75.8 %) at low temperature. Conversely, the CZA-H2 (Cu+/Cu0 = 1.43) catalyst and CZA-CO-CO2 (Cu+/Cu0 = 8.35) catalyst showed relatively poor methanol selectivity. Meanwhile, a regular correlation between the methanol selectivity and Cu+/Cu0 ratio of the catalyst was observed. The appropriate Cu+/Cu0 ratio is favorable for the adsorption of CO2 and the formation and adsorption of methanol intermediates, which helps to improve the selectivity of methanol. These findings will serve as valuable guidance in the design of highly efficient catalysts, optimizing the activation procedures and achieving the desired Cu+/Cu0 ratio. coredata.dc:description: The pre-activation of Cu-based catalysts is an important step to fully develop their catalytic potential. The production of active species (Cu+ and Cu0) which play the active site role generally occurs in the activation stage by reducing from Cu2+. Herein, the Cu+/Cu0 ratio of CuZnOAl2O3 (CZA) catalysts was adjusted using different activation atmospheres and the relationship between Cu+/Cu0 ratio of the catalyst and methanol selectivity from CO2 hydrogenation was investigated in detail. Combined with X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation spectroscopy (DRIFTS) characterization, etc. and experimental results, it was observed that the selectivity of methanol was obviously relied on the Cu+/Cu0 ratio of CZA catalyst. This work provides theoretical guidance and feasible scheme to rationally design and optimize the required catalysts.
